/COMMIT_MSG.message: Sorry, I thought I had catched them all in previous reviews

In what way is it odd? Can you describe an example or a use case/reason you wished to see usage info when listing or showing inventory?

I want to understand the motivation for adding this being that there are already commands around showing usage:

https://docs.openstack.org/osc-placement/latest/cli/index.html#resource-provider-usage-show

https://docs.openstack.org/osc-placement/latest/cli/index.html#resource-usage-show

> In what way is it odd? Can you describe an example or a use
 > case/reason you wished to see usage info when listing or showing
 > inventory?

Updated the commit message to better state my reasoning, along with my intent to deprecate those separate commands in the future (I don't think they should exist as separate commands). As I mentioned on IRC, I run into this every time I need to do a bit of querying of placement and I doubt I'm alone. I can't think of a practical case where you would be querying available inventory from placement and wouldn't find the usage information helpful. osc-placement is mostly a debugging tool for admins, after all.

 > I want to understand the motivation for adding this being that
 > there are already commands around showing usage:
 > 
 > https://docs.openstack.org/osc-placement/latest/cli/index.html#resource-provider-usage-show

As noted above, IMO this command should not exist, at least not in its current form. Its output should be part of 'resource provider inventory (list|show)'.

If we were to retain this as a separate command, I'd like to provide far more detailed output that we currently do. Namely, I'd like to show a breakdown of usage by each allocation. This is currently available, but only through the rather obscure 'resource provider show $RP_UUID --allocations' command.

 > https://docs.openstack.org/osc-placement/latest/cli/index.html#resource-usage-show

This is different. This shows total usage for a given project, not per-RP usage. This should stay unless/until we have an API and related command to describe total amounts of inventory available for use by the project, in which case we should fold this command into that one.

-1: This is super inefficient, we are creating the whole dict for every single command we send!

I still believe creating this whole dict for every command when we only care about 1 element is not right.

There are multiple ways to do it:

We could add a class attribute with dict of lambdas:

 vpsa_commands = {
     'attach_volume': lambda kwargs: (
         'POST',
         '/api/servers/%s/volumes.json' % kwargs.get('vpsa_srv'),
         {'volume_name[]': kwargs.get('vpsa_vol'),
          'access_type': kwargs.get('share_proto'),
          'readonly': kwargs.get('read_only'),
          'force': 'YES'}),

     . . .
 }

And then here on L243 we would just use it to construct the data we care about:

 method, url, params = vpsa_commands[cmd](kwargs)


Or we could create methods called "_cmd_<cmd-name>" for example:

 @staticmethod
 def _cmd_attach_volume(kwargs):
     return (
         'POST',
         '/api/servers/%s/volumes.json' % kwargs.get('vpsa_srv'),
         {'volume_name[]': kwargs.get('vpsa_vol'),
          'access_type': kwargs.get('share_proto'),
          'readonly': kwargs.get('read_only'),
          'force': 'YES'}
     )

And then here on L243 we would just call the method:

 method, url, params = getattr(self, '_cmd_' + cmd)(kwargs)
The commands require variable arguments, making it unable to store as an instance attribute.
You added PUT at line 261, maybe it should be added here also?  (You don't have to, I'm just asking in case you missed it.)
Done

And then here on L243 we would just use it to construct the data we care about:

Or we could create methods called "_cmd_<cmd-name>" for example:

 @staticmethod

     return (
         'POST',
         '/api/servers/%s/volumes.json' % kwargs.get('vpsa_srv'),
         {'volume_name[]': kwargs.get('vpsa_vol'),
          'access_type': kwargs.get('share_proto'),

And then here on L243 we would just call the method:

I agree with Gorka that the current code is a super-inefficient way to do this.  Most drivers follow his second suggestion (a bunch of specific _cmd_<name>() functions), but the dict of lambdas is definitely cool.  If you are pressed for time, you can do it in a follow up patch.  But you should definitely fix it -- when people add new drivers, they look at current drivers for a reference point, and you don't want to set a bad example!

I don't understand the difference in this driver's case for 'name' and 'display_name', and I'm getting confused with Cinder's name and display_name.

Below is a sample of the volume query response from the zadara backend:

{"name":"volume-00000064","display_name":"OS_volume-a262dba9-937a-4057-88f3-f0eba2e6ad44","cg_display_name":"OS_volume-a262dba9-937a-4057-88f3-f0eba2e6ad44","cg_name":"cg-00000064","cg_user_created":"NO","pool_display_name":"RAID-10-Pool-1","pool_name":"pool-00010001","pool_version":2,"av_scan_policy_name":null,"status":"Available","provisioned_capacity":1,"server_name":null," .....}

For each cinder volume with given name as "volume.name", zadara driver will use a template and creates a volume at the backend with display_name as "(OS_<volume.name>)". The volume response field "name" corresponds to the backend id(volume-00000064). This backend 'id' is stored in cinder volume as provider_location.

I hope I am able to explain and reduce the confusion. Please do not correlate terms like id,name of the cinder volume with zadara backend volume. Thanks.

nova/compute/manager.py.message: you're technically recreating the client at every period in time. Any way to stop doing and either use a global object or a class object ?

I'm a bit afraid by the number of HTTP API hits we would make if the periodic time is short. Fortunately, the default value is 3600 secs, but I'd recommend to amend the conf option documentation to mention that performance penalty if you configured Cyborg.

i dont think this is a concern.
we will only call to cyborg if the instance has cyborg resouces because of the if on line 9479
and we will only do it once per instance that was shelved. so unless you are constantly shelving instnace in very large numbers the period of this will not really be a ddos vector as most instance will skip this code path.

To be clear, I'll restate my concern with an example : 
say a periodic time is 3600, meaning this method runs every 3600 secs.
During this timeframe, instances can be created and shelved for every tenant. At the end of this timeframe, this periodic task will run and pick all instances that were shelved during the last hour. This could be large, like 10k. Then, it will iterate over those 10k instances to offload, and ask the Cyborg API nearly concurrently. This can be a serious performance penalty if the Cyborg API isn't robust to cope with 10000 connections.

I dont think this is a concern too.
We will filter the SHELVED instance in Line9463, and if the instance timeout of the shelved_offload_time, it will be set to SHELVING_OFFLOADING, and there is not really to do *this*.
my concern from PS2 isn't addressed.

@Slyvain: if you are concerned that we are instantiating cyborgclient is costly and we are doing it in a loop then we can simply move the client creation top of the loop, then it will only create once per periodic run.

I looked at Cyborg API reference and unfortunately, the ARQ resource API doesn't accept more than one instance UUID (1). That being said, we could maybe get all the ARQs before (for example in L9473) and look at some dict for getting the ARQ UUIDs related to each instance here, so we would then only have one HTTP call for all the instances, and not one per instance, which I'm still a bit afraid ?

(1) https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/accelerator/v2/index.html?expanded=list-accelerator-requests-detail,get-one-accelerator-request-detail

It is a tradeoff. 

A) If the system has a lot of ARQ spread across a lot of computes then querying every ARQ and then filtering here down to the ARQs that belongs to shelved instances on this compute is pretty costly. 

B) In the other hand if this compute has a lot of shelved instances with device profile then querying ARQs for each, one by one, is costly too. 

The ultimate solution would be to query ARQs for a list of instances in a single request as suggested by Sylvain but that is not supported today by cyborg API. 

So we have to figure out what scenario is more likely. A) or B). I think the number of accelerators per compute is the limiting factor. We cannot have 1000 of accelerators per compute as they are physical hardware but we can have 1000 computes with some accelerators. So I think scenario A) is more likely and therefore asking cyborg for each instance one by one is the better solution until a batch query is implemented in cyborg API.

> It is a tradeoff. 
> 
> A) If the system has a lot of ARQ spread across a lot of computes then querying every ARQ and then filtering here down to the ARQs that belongs to shelved instances on this compute is pretty costly. 
> 
> B) In the other hand if this compute has a lot of shelved instances with device profile then querying ARQs for each, one by one, is costly too. 
> 
> The ultimate solution would be to query ARQs for a list of instances in a single request as suggested by Sylvain but that is not supported today by cyborg API. 
> 
> So we have to figure out what scenario is more likely. A) or B). I think the number of accelerators per compute is the limiting factor. We cannot have 1000 of accelerators per compute as they are physical hardware but we can have 1000 computes with some accelerators. So I think scenario A) is more likely and therefore asking cyborg for each instance one by one is the better solution until a batch query is implemented in cyborg API.

Agree, we can support the B solution firstly, then we will add the batch query ARQs for a list of the instance in a single request to cyborg list, and after we completed that feature (Maybe in Xena release, and I will take this to Cybrog PTG [1] to discuss), I will update this periodic task.

After support the batch query ARQs API for more intances in a single request, we can reduce requesting cyborg times, but we also need to loop the ARQ instances to shelve_offload_instance().

[1]https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/cyborg-xena-ptg

i assume someone asked for 409 to be used instead.
it was intetnioally using a 403 before becasue that is what we used for cyborg
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/780333/5/nova/api/openstack/compute/evacuate.py#131
which is what we said we would emulate.

a 409 can also work but it will then be different then cyborg.
409 generally implies you can rety the operation with the same data and it might
eventually succed where as 403 imples you are not allowed to take the operation
which i think is more corect in this case.

can you leave a comment as to why we are deviating form the spec  as i noted here:
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/780866/2/releasenotes/notes/vdpa-cc2300d2c46c150b.yaml#15

Stepehen changed this to 409, I have no hard opinion. When I did similar block for qos ops then it was 400. At that time mriedem wondered about 409[1] but was OK with 400 as MultiattachNotSupportedOldMicroversion was also 400. The common guide does not have this case handled in [2]. 

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/630725/4/nova/api/openstack/compute/shelve.py#22
[2] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/api-wg/guidelines/http/response-codes.html

I went with 409 because it aligned with what we were doing for unsupported operations with SEV or vTPM [1]. I get the confusion. In theory, you _could_ get this working by changing the request and using an instance without SEV/vTPM/vDPA, but that of course isn't really practical if you want to e.g. live migrate *this* VM.

If we change this again to HTTP 400, can we also change the vTPM, SEV and cyborg cases to return HTTP 400?

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/b7334b508955ce99d6ae3765bf78e68572b83f56/nova/exception.py#L528-L537

I think this section in api-wg cover this most closely- https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/api-wg/guidelines/http/response-codes.html#use-of-501-not-implemented

400 is something what api-wg guidelines suggest and IMO too most closely appropriate return code. this request can be considered as invalid request until this operation is tested or fixed. If we see other Non Supported features, we do 400 for most of them - https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/exception.py#L285-L325

409 convey that you can get this operation working if you resolve the conflict either by some request data or changing the resource state or so, that is why I feel 409 is little confusing here.

403 is also fine but I prefer 400 for not supported operation as 403 can be interpreted as "ask your admin to allow this operation for you".

As summary, 400 is most close correct and then 403. 409 is surly not so correct here.

Yes we can do 400 for all such cases and have consistency. 400 is always a valid return code for all API[1] so does not require microversion bump.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/contributor/microversions.html#id3
added a topic to discuss on consistent return code for such cases in PTG L267 https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/nova-xena-ptg

gerritbot/bot.py.message: Should we also log something here? I guess that might be good just to leave a breadcrumb when someone goes log spelunking to find out why some change wasn't announced.

I considered that, but truncation in this case means we leave off the end of the change URL, which isn't especially helpful. Also when a commit message is that malformed, it's more likely noise not worth announcing anyway. If someone wants to work out a way to front-load length checking of the commit subject string and calculate a safe limit before assembling the message passed into this method, then that would be cool as a follow-up change. The point of this change is simply to avoid unnecessary reconnects when such a change comes across the event stream.

What about also truncating messages that are too long? The RFC appears to say a message can be a maximum of 512 characters. Though the command and CR/LF are part of the message.

I would think 400-450 characters as a limit on what is sent what be plenty.


[0] https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1459#section-2.3

Ya, we can trim it down to a reasonable length and then if we still end up over (due to utf8 binary encoding or long channel names or long gerrit Full Names, etc) we can skip then. But we can add that in a followup. Another options woudl be to split the message on whitespace and send it in multiple chunks.

environments/barbican-backend-simple-cry.message:
Don't think that registry mapping in L13 would work without these parameters when this environment is included as is, i.e BarbicanSimpleCryptoKek does not have a default[1]. 

If we want to avoid this being included unintentionally, we should probably comment out everything and also update the text mentioning that user have to uncomment both sections.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/deployment/barbican/barbican-backend-simple-crypto-puppet.yaml#L31

So I think this is one of those odd things we require end users to do to enable services.  Techincally they need to provide that parameter, but it doesn't make sense to modify the THT version of this file. There would be two things that a user needs to do and it would be include -e THT/environments/barbican-backend-simple-crypto.yaml and include the BarbicanSimpleCrypto* params in another environment file (e.g. user params)  I know a lot of times these are example files and the expectation would be for a user to copy this somewhere and modify, but they would also need to update the path for the services reference.  IMHO i think the documentation should be updated to point that they need to include these params somewhere (it doesn't have to be this file)

I think environments are expected to be self contained (at least from heat pov, i.e supposed to contain registry mappings and parameter_defaults required for those). Also, those are called 'parameter_defaults' for a reason, defaults unless overridden. With the tht interface we've to enable services (include specific environments), IMO, they should have all parameter_defaults required and not expect users to specify it in some other environment for it to work by default.

this is repeated below, after the code that was moved. Is this intentional?

Yes.  The _assess_interface_groups function modifies the two lists (side-effects FTW), and each call checks for different sets of interfaces and updates the lists accordingly.

The reason the check against OPTIONAL_INTERFACES was moved down was because it was causing less important info (waiting for etcd so it can to transition to HA) to shadow info that required direct user intervention (uninitialized, sealed, missing CA, etc).

I don't know what the registry is.

Yes, I think this makes only sense when looking at how the event queues are used in the scheduler. Basically the registry allows accessing a tenants pipeline event queue as follows:

    queue_registry = PipelineManagementEventQueue.createRegistry(self.zk_client)
    assert isinstance(
        queue_registry["tenant_name"]["pipeline_name"],
        PipelineManagementEventQueue
    )

I'm honestly confused when to use camelCase vs snake_case in Zuul. I was under the impression that it's mostly camelCase, but snake_case for private methods. I tried to follow that style, (I might have used snake_case out of habit sometimes). From your update it now seems it should be camelCase for everything (except properties?!).

Yeah, it's not perfectly consistent, sorry.  :(  It's supposed to be camelCase for everything.  Sometimes things slip through and it's admittedly less important for internal methods that are only used in the same file.  I think it was the public "create_registry" method that made me think the rework was worth doing.

And, yes, this essentially follows the old Java convention: CapitalClasses.camelCaseMethods() and .snake_case_attributes.  That was fairly common in python 1.5.2 days and not unheard of in the early 2.x versions.  People don't acknowledge that now though.  Anyway, if we started from scratch or decided to do a major reformatting, I'd go with the current style.  But in the mean time, consistency, or at least as close as we can get, is worth it.
Ok, thanks for clarifying.

This deletes the original event before reporting the result, so if the scheduler crashes between these two lines, the caller will wait forever.  I think it may be safer to reverse the order.  I'm going to go ahead and do that in my revision, but this is pretty delicate, so I want to make sure you agree.  I'll leave a note about the importance of it.
Yes, good catch. I think it's better for the result to be set twice in the case the event processing is interrupted than to let the caller run into a timeout (or worse hang forever).

I like that suggestion; we may have other things that need garbage collecting.  I don't think we would need to run this very often (maybe every hour?) and it could delete things that are, say, >24 old.

Why is the result created as an ephemeral node?  If the scheduler crashes between reporting the result and the client reading it, then the client won't see the result.

Ideally we want the client to delete the event after deleting it in order to avoid having these stick around for the lifetime of the scheduler anyway.  But we can't rely on the client doing that, because someone may have hit CTRL-C.  So I think we should do the following:

1) Don't create the nodes as ephemeral.
2) Have the client delete the node (this is already the case).
3) Periodically look for leaked result nodes and delete them.

Here's an alternative (but I don't think we should do this):

Currently the client ignores the data in the result callback in favor of simply performing a ZK get on the znode.  If we used the data from the callback instead of re-reading it, we would not be subject to the race with the server crashing before the client reads the data.  That might be worth doing just to save a ZK read call, however, it still doesn't solve the issue of clients not cleaning up results and them sticking around until the server exits.  For that reason alone, I think we should drop the ephemeral flag and add a cleanup process.

Should this cleanup procedure be something specific to the event queues or would some kind of scheduler global cleanup hook be better? Something like:

    scheduler.register_cleanup_hook(mgmt_queue.cleanup)

Based on your response to the earlier patchset and the code in the tests, I think I understand what this is now.  But if I'm following it correctly, couldn't we use a dictionary keyed by tuple instead?

This is fine.  We need the defaultkeydict in order to pass in the reference to the client, so we may as well stick with this.  If we didn't need that, I would be in favor of simplifying it with a plain dict indexed by tuple.

Yes, we could. The API would look something like this:

    event_queue[tenant.name, pipeline.name]

Personally I like the nested dict syntax better (tuples as keys looks a little unfamiliar to me), but it's an easy change in case you'd prefer that.
I like this method of suppressing a distinct exception :)

I think these are backwards?  get_kwargs appears to always be used, kwargs is only used in .find()

I understand the bug, and that is fine.  the 'get' name makes sense to you because you know what it is doing.  We rarely use/know the HTTP method used in any of our API calls, that's the leaky part.  We can leave the name, it's just not really how the arg is used from the 'callers' point of view.

And get_kwargs are included in the .find() call since they are combined into kwargs.  Again, from the caller's POV they are still present and used:

* first .get() uses get_kwargs, returns if success
* second .get() uses get_kwargs, returns if success
* get_kwargs is merged into kwargs
* third .get() effectively uses get_kwargs + kwargs, returns if success
* first .find() effectively uses get_kwargs + kwargs

agree, it's not necessary to copy all params from lower catalogues to upper all the time. it's possible to modify any catalogue param even from 'site' level by the following sequence in transformer: set  needed variable in transformer+ call replacement transformers after that.  
It's needed only if there are several lower functions, that must have the same values in their catalog and in that case composite level will define this var and copy it's value to all necessary catalogs of lower functions in its replacement.
Since document patching is performed before transformers are applied, a simple patch to a catalogue at the site-level should get picked up by any "imported" transformers, right?

in 2 words - yes. to be more precise - patches are also done by transformers, but external transformes are executed after inbuilt transofrmers. here is more info: https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/kustomize/blob/master/docs/howItWorks.md

manifests/type/test-workload/phases/work.message: I think 'transformers' is better. we don't know if we use only replacement transformers in future. and kustomize 'terminology' calls this transformers. I suggest to rename everywhere to keep more 'generic' name.

I think it's a question of:

1) what transformers will we want to "export" to be applied at lower levels, vs, taking the simpler approach of applying transformers "within" a module?  Replacements have to be exported because they can't be applied till e.g. site-level data is available.  Can you think of other examples?

2) will we always want to apply the transformer (replacements + etc) at the same time, e.g., at the site level? -- if we do decide to export them, then applying them consistently at site level seems reasonable to me.

In general I like "replacements" better because it IS less generic.  However, if we need to do this kind of thing for multiple transformers then it would probably be more convenient to bundle them into one kustomization.

The only use case that's coming to my mind though, might be if we needed to export generators, which may make sense to define in a generic module and then apply at the site.  However generators aren't transformers :) so we might need to come up with an even more generic name in that case...

>1. ... 
I don't see any that we want to export so far...
That's because we don't plan to use functions separately - only via site level. And because modules are suppoesed always to follow the same behavior: we have catalog + resources in it. if you want to change resources - you need to change catalog and execute transformers. That behavior is similar to what helm does, with only difference that helm generates resources based on values.yaml, and we transform resources based on catalog.yaml. It is simple, it's transparent.

> 2 ...
kustomization/kustomization.yaml will be a bit weird :)
one more option is 'transformations'... But.. I don't really want to push here:
it's not a big deal if we keep 'replacements' if you like it and hope that replacements will be the only type of transformers (I'm not 100% sure, because Airship2 should have a pretty long history in future and probably there will be new ideas related to transformers). Again if we keep 1 repo it's not a big deal. The only concern I think of - that later renaming will be a breaking change when we switch to multi-repostory model. because it will be necessary to simultaneously change all repos. But again -it's a terminology. for kustomize it doesn't matter how this catalog is named. it will work whatever we call it :) The only person who won't be happy if we have more transformers in future and still have 'replacements' as a name will be my internal 'perfectionist' :) .

A few things here probably make sense to split out into a more generic VariableCatalog, which would be used by multiple functions.  However, since those catalogues don't exist yet, we could put in TODO comments with the desired "final destination" inline here if you'd like.

pod-network -- Unless we want to have a different pod network from the target cluster for some reason, it would make sense to share this value, since the target cluster will need it a few places.  Perhaps similar this "site-networking" example, but a "general-networking" or something that lives at the type level?  https://review.opendev.org/#/c/724869/21/manifests-example/site/test-workload/shared/catalogues/site-networking.yaml

k8s-version -- We'll likely want to share that between the ephemeral and target clusters, so we only have to update one place when we adopt a new k8s version.  This should go in a versions catalogue, which hasn't been defined yet.

Same thing for calico-version, konfigadm-version.

For the things that are completely specific to the ephemeral function, it probably makes sense to leave them in an ephemeral-vars catalogue like you have.

The variable catalogue is in progress here: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/746608/

Can we revisit this catalogue in the SIG-YAML call, and talk through,

1. what are the right "homes" for this info, especially for things that need to be shared beyond the ephemeral function

2. for the remaining things that are specific to the ephemeral function, is an ephemeral-vars function still the right approach, or would simple patching make sense?  The answer to #2 is probably dependent on #1.

Now that we are using `airshipctl phase run` in 31_deploy_initinfra_target_node.sh this should no longer be necessary, since that should be waiting for CRD/Deployment/etc automatically.

There are two reasons why this is needed.
1. The 31_*initinfra*.sh is a generic script which does not normally include these CRDs, they are additionally added by kustomization only for this feature.
2. It has been experimentally seen, even though the phase waits for objects and exits successfully, if used immediately after, the CRD is sometimes seen to fail! This check ensures the success of the next phase (i.e. 'workload').

As for the use of 'phase run', I'll refer to the team for their decision and action...

> There are two reasons why this is needed.
 > 1. The 31_*initinfra*.sh is a generic script which does not
 > normally include these CRDs, they are additionally added by
 > kustomization only for this feature.

That script includes `airshipctl phase run initinfra-target` which will always include the CRDs and Helm Operator Deployment.

 > 2. It has been experimentally seen, even though the phase waits for
 > objects and exits successfully, if used immediately after, the CRD
 > is sometimes seen to fail! This check ensures the success of the
 > next phase (i.e. 'workload').

Maybe we weren't using wait logic in the past in 31_... `airshipctl phase apply` at some time in the past, but with `airshipctl phase run` this should always run wait logic, which includes waiting for Deployments and CRDs, so we should no longer need to do that separately here. This will be important to rely on the wait logic when moving to using phase plans. If you still do see an issue, it would be helpful to see those Zuul logs.
we should use `airshipctl phase run` and phase documents now that we are using them everywhere else, see https://review.opendev.org/#/c/749419/ for how to do that

I think the one tricky part should be how to reuse the existing phase documents and add new ones to it in a shared directory that you can point at. Perhaps you can copy all of them to a temp directory for this purpose.
